content.title: Theoretical Minimum Action (Quantum of Action)
content.abstract: The Planck constant ℏ is the fundamental quantum of action, representing the minimum indivisible unit of the action integral that governs quantum mechanics.

what_is_action.classical_definition: S = ∫L dt = ∫(T-V) dt (time integral of Lagrangian)

why_action_is_quantized.explanation: Closed orbits enclose integer multiples of h
Paths with action difference >> ℏ interfere destructively

why_action_is_quantized.formula: Δx Δp ≥ ℏ/2, ΔE Δt ≥ ℏ/2
why_action_is_quantized.explanation: ℏ sets the scale of quantum uncertainty

physical_manifestations.interpretation: Each photon carries one quantum of action per radian
ℏ is the quantum of orbital angular momentum
Superfluid vortex circulation quantized in h/m

action_and_distinguishability.classical_limit: When S >> ℏ, quantum effects negligible
action_and_distinguishability.quantum_regime: When S ~ ℏ, quantum interference dominates
action_and_distinguishability.interpretation: ℏ sets the 'resolution' of phase space - cells smaller than ℏ are indistinguishable

can_action_be_smaller_than_h.explanation: A single photon, regardless of frequency, represents one 'quantum of action' in a sense
can_action_be_smaller_than_h.subtlety: Low-energy photon has E = ℏω, and over time T = 2π/ω, total action S = ET = h

comparison_with_classical.classical_action: Can be arbitrarily small in principle
comparison_with_classical.quantum_action: Comes in lumps of ℏ for transitions
comparison_with_classical.correspondence_principle: Classical behavior emerges when S >> ℏ
